div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, November 2, 1900
div1.p:
Of all the silly and nonsensical rig-
marole about yellow fever that has yet
found its way into print--and there has
been enough of it to load a fleet--the
silliest beyond compare is to be found in
the arguments and theories engendered by
the mosquito hypothesis. Moreover, won-
derful to relate, the climax of idiocy seems
to have been reached in a dispatch to the
New York Sun of the 1st of November
from New Orleans. Evidently the Sun's
press report must have been turned in by
some one who has not lived in New Or-
leans two consecutive years or who, if he
has lived there at all, has never taken
counsel of any well-informed person. Let
us consider a specimen gem of thought
from this amazing publication:

“In past epidemics the piney woods of Louisiana
and Mississippi, only a few miles from the coast,
were considered a safe refuge from the fever, and
it was attributed to the sanitary influence of the
pines, without any good reason therefor. The fact
that the mosquito is unknown in those woods, save
in a few bottoms along the streams, would give a
better explanation of the absence of the disease, or
rather its failure to spread, even when persons
already infected with the disease seek refuge among
the pines. The report of the board of army medi-
cal men explains what has heretofore been a mys-
tery.” ...

The last genuine epidemic of yellow
fever in this country occurred in 1878,
twenty-two years ago. Since then there
have been some local visitations, here one
year and there the next, but never gen-
erally prevalent or in any proper sense of
the word an epidemic. In 1878, however,
the disease spread almost everywhere
south of the Ohio River and west of the
Appalachian range. Atlanta opened her
gates to the afflicted fugitives, many of
whom had the fever and either died or
recovered in that city. The disease did not
spread there at all. In other towns of the
South it spread like wildfire. The town of
Tangipahoa, about eighty-five miles north
of New Orleans, was almost depopulated,
yet it is situated in the typical piney
woods and is not particularly long on
mosquitoes. Fifteen miles south of Tan-
gipahoa is Amite, lying on much lower
ground and quite near to the great swamps
which separate it from the river coast and
the sugar belt. Amite maintained no
quarantine. Communication with New Or-
leans was practically uninterrupted. Mos-
quitoes were in countless myriads in its
immediate neighborhood. Yet Amite, with
no quarantine and unlimited mosquitoes,
went scot free, while Tangipahoa, in the
sand hills and piney woods, with a shot-
gun quarantine and a scant supply of
mosquitoes, was a veritable shambles. Go-
ing further north, into Mississippi, we find
that the forlorn little railroad towns in
the pine region were as mercilessly visited
as the river towns, even in the alluvial
region above Vicksburg. Holly Springs
suffered perhaps more than Vicksburg and
Greenville. The scourge went where it
pleased, mosquitoes or no mosquitoes, pine
ridge or swamp, and no human being
knew then or knows now why or how it
went. If it were a fact, which it is not,
that “the mosquito is unknown in those
woods” (the pine districts of Louisiana
and Mississippi) this proposition might be
entitled to respectful consideration. One
might at least build upon it a reasonably
specious theory. As things are, however,
the “mystery” remains, notwithstanding
this “board of army medical men,” who-
ever they may be.
But the real bonne-bouche comes last:

“The authorities in the piney woods towns also
call attention to the remarkable fact that while ice
will not kill the germ, as is shown by the reap-
pearance of the disease after the bitter winter of
1897, it (presumably the disease) disappears after
a light frost. This can easily be explained by the
mosquito theory, for the lightest frost kills off the
mosquitoes, and the disease disappears simulta-
neously with them.” ...

No doubt this interesting postulate
would attract attention were it based upon
the very thinnest ground of fact, but the
proposition “that the lightest frost kills
off the mosquitoes, and the disease disap-
pears simultaneously with them,” is so
utterly preposterous as to forbid a serious
thought. Any one who has lived in the
far South--in what is known as the yel-
low fever belt--knows that neither a
light frost nor any other kind of a frost
“kills off the mosquitoes.” Any one who
has had experience of yellow fever along
our Gulf coast knows that the only func-
tion of a light frost is to make the disease
more dangerous. In that region, where
yellow fever is exotic, really cold weather
invariably arrests an epidemic, but it does
not harm the mosquito more than once in
a century, and even then the pest lives in
the dwellings and resumes business the
moment the houses are heated for human
occupation.

There is absolutely nothing in this mos-
quito hypothesis as submitted to the New
York Sun. It is not even comparable to
the duster-broom-carbolic acid hypothe-
sis, for thoroughly scientific sanitation at
least alleviates some of the conditions
which contribute to the success of Yellow
Jack's assault.
